questions.question_text: Which two overlay network design considerations must be made for a Cisco SD-Access network? (Choose two.)

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An architect is designing a routing solution for a company. The new design will add a circuit routers C and D to protect against loss of connectivity to 10.0.4.0/24 during a link failure between routers B and D. Which solution must the architect choose?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://networklessons.com/cisco/ccie-routing-switching-written/eigrp-stub-leak-map

Why not "A"?
"Stub connected" should advertise connected networks?

comments.content: This is because the 10.0.4.0/24 network is only a connected network on Router D - so if the link goes down between D and B, even if Stub Connected was configured on Router C, it would not advertise Router D's network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

questions.question_text: A company needs to increase access port capacity on one floor of a building. They want to leverage the existing catalyst access switch. There is no problem with uplink bandwidth capacity. However, no additional uplinks can be added because no ports are available on the distribution switches. Which solution must the company choose to provide additional access ports?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Catalyst Switch - Stackwise

comments.content: The question is referencing access switches though, not distribution switches. Both solutions could work, but VSS requires exiting interfaces to be available on the switch, and the question states that the access switch ports have been exhausted.
*Existing, not exiting. My vote is for stackwise, answer D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Could be VSS or Stackwise depending on the question. The question wording is terrible. Being more ports are needed at the distribution layer I'd say answer is VSS as Stackwise is an access layer technology and not typically used on distribution switches.

Selected Answer: D
D. Stackwise

The company should choose Cisco StackWise technology to provide additional access ports. StackWise allows multiple Cisco Catalyst switches to be interconnected, creating a single logical switch with increased port capacity. This solution helps to expand the access layer without needing additional uplinks to the distribution switches. StackWise technology simplifies management and increases the resiliency of the network.
no additional ports can be added -- same floor-- STackwise
D stackwise seems the right answer

questions.question_text: Which queuing structure is used on SD-WAN Edge routers?

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/qos/vEdge-20-x/qos-book/forwarding-qos.html

On Cisco vEdge devices and Cisco IOS XE SD-WAN devices, each interface has eight queues, which are numbered 0 to 7. Queue 0 is reserved, and is used for both control traffic and low-latency queuing (LLQ) traffic. For LLQ, any class that is mapped to queue 0 must also be configured to use LLQ. Queues 1 to 7 are available for data traffic, and the default scheduling for these seven queues is weighted round-robin (WRR). For these queues, you can define the weighting according to the needs of your network. When QoS is not configured for data traffic, queue 2 is the default queue.

LLQ+WRR - but no such option.

Selected Answer: B
The question is for the Queue schedule. On Cisco vEdge devices and Cisco IOS XE Catalyst SD-WAN devices, each interface has eight queues, which are numbered 0 to 7. Queue 0 is reserved, and is used for both control traffic and low-latency queuing (LLQ) traffic. For LLQ, any class that is mapped to queue 0 must also be configured to use LLQ. Queues 1 to 7 are available for data traffic, and the default scheduling for these seven queues is weighted round-robin (WRR). For these queues, you can define the weighting according to the needs of your network. When QoS is not configured for data traffic, queue 2 is the default queue. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/qos/ios-xe-17/qos-book-xe/forwarding-qos.html

Selected Answer: C
The queuing structure commonly used on SD-WAN Edge routers is "1P-4Q-2T" (1 Priority queue, 4 Queues, 2 Thresholds).

In this queuing structure, different types of traffic can be classified and placed into separate queues based on their priority or class of service. It offers better control over traffic prioritization and quality of service. The priority queue is typically used for real-time traffic like voice, while the other queues are used for different levels of traffic prioritization.

Selected Answer: B
Certainly not Priority. Priority Queuing = PQ is a set of four queues that is served in strict-priority order. The major drawback of this method is the starvation of lower-priority traffic. The only possible answer is LLQ+WFQ, however actual answer should be LLQ+WRR. Also SD-WAN has 8 queues unlike the 4 queues that is defined by Priority Queuing.

Selected Answer: B
this seems to be the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
On Cisco vEdge devices and Cisco IOS XE SD-WAN devices, each interface has eight queues, which are numbered 0 to 7. Queue 0 is reserved, and is used for both control traffic and low-latency queuing (LLQ) traffic. For LLQ, any class that is mapped to queue 0 must also be configured to use LLQ. Queues 1 to 7 are available for data traffic, and the default scheduling for these seven queues is weighted round-robin (WRR). For these queues, you can define the weighting according to the needs of your network. When QoS is not configured for data traffic, queue 2 is the default queue.

B. LLQ+WFQ
https://www.networkacademy.io/ccie-enterprise/sdwan/qos#:~:text=When%20a%20WAN%20edge%20router,is%20used%20for%20control%20traffic.
WFQ uses weighted round robin scheduling and allows you to configure the weighting as a percentage of the bandwidth.. So LLQ+WFQ ? "B" looks ok to me.
